Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery band-cup; interior glazed black; exterior: from top, part of black band; below, black-figure decoration consisting of youth to right (only lower body missing; in chiton with added red, holding a sword in his right hand); at right, horse (hindquarters remaining) to right; at left, point of spear held by a now lost figure; nonsense inscription on exterior.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Group of Villa Giulia 3559 (compare)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Beazley attributes the sherd to near the Group of Villa Giulia 3559. He interprets the rightmost figure as either a horse or a centaur in ABV, though had earlier suggested a battle between Lapiths and centaurs to Lamb (quoted in CVA).
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 42, pl. XXI, no. 30)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 403, no. B602)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1403) (phase 3)
